qas.question: Which rooms are used for less formal entertaining such as luncheons or private audiences?
Which room is named for visit of Tsar Nicolas I of Russia?
The 1855 Room is name for which European emperor?
Guests attending the Queen's Garden Parties will mostly likely see which room?
Where are the suites located that the Queen and Prince Phillip use?
What is the name of the slightly less luxurious staterooms located underneath the State Apartments?
What type of entertaining are the semi-state apartments used for?
Who is the 1844 Room named after?
Who is the 1855 Room named after?
Where are the Queen and Prince Phillip's apartments located?
Which rooms are used for more formal entertaining such as luncheons or public audiences?
Which room does not allow visits by Tsar Nicolas I of Russia?
Which European chef is The 1845 Room named after?
Where are the suites located that the King and Prince Phillip use?
Who is the 1744 Room named after?

context: Directly underneath the State Apartments is a suite of slightly less grand rooms known as <a0_0><b10_0>the <a5_0>semi-state apartments<b10_0/><a5_0/><a0_0/>. Opening from the Marble Hall, these rooms are used for <a6_0>less formal entertaining<a6_0/>, such as luncheon parties and private audiences. Some of the rooms are named and decorated for particular visitors, such as the <a1_0><b11_0>1844 Room<b11_0/><a1_0/>, decorated in that year for the State visit of <a7_0><b14_0>Tsar Nicholas I of Russia<b14_0/><a7_0/>, and, on the other side of the Bow Room, the 1855 Room, in honour of the visit of <a2_0><a8_0><b12_0>Emperor Napoleon III of France<b12_0/><a8_0/><a2_0/>. At the centre of this suite is the <a3_0>Bow Room<a3_0/>, through which thousands of guests pass annually to the Queen's Garden Parties in the Gardens. The Queen and Prince Philip use a smaller suite of rooms in <a4_0><a9_0><b13_0>the north wing<b13_0/><a9_0/><a4_0/>.
